1.segment: BACKGROUND AND PURPOSE : To evaluate the results of low-dose radiation therapy ( LD-RT ) to lungs in the management of patients with COVID-19 pneumonia .

2.segment: MATERIAL AND METHODS : We conducted a prospective phase I-II trial enrolling COVID-19 patients ≥ 50 years-old ,

3.segment: with bilateral lung involvement at imaging study and oxygen requirement ( oxygen saturation ≤ 93 % on room air ) .

4.segment: Patients received 1 Gy to whole lungs in a single fraction .

5.segment: Primary outcome was a radiological response assessed as severity and extension scores at days +3 and +7 .

6.segment: Secondary outcomes were toxicity ( CTCAE v5 .0 ) ,

7.segment: days of hospitalization , changes in inflammatory blood parameters ( ferritin , lymphocytes , C-reactive protein , d-dimer and LDH ) and SatO2 / FiO2 index ( SAFI ) ,

9.segment: Descriptive analyses were summarized as means with standard deviation ( SD ) and/or medians with interquartile ranges ( IQR ) .

10.segment: A Wilcoxon sign rank test for paired data was used to assess the CT scores and Chi Square was used to assess for comparison of categorical variables .

13.segment: Eighteen patients ( 44 % ) previously received an anti-COVID treatment ( tocilizumab , lopinavir/ritonavir , remdesivir ) and thirty-two patients ( 84 % ) received steroids during LD-RT .

14.segment: The extension score improved significantly ( p = 0.02 ) on day +7 .

15.segment: Mean baseline extension score was 13.7 ( SD ± 4.9 ) with a score of 12.2 ( ± 5.2 ) at day 3 ,

17.segment: No differences were found in the severity score .

18.segment: SAFI improved significantly on day +3 and + 7 ( p < 0.01 ) .

19.segment: Median SAFI on day 0 was 147 ( IQR 118-264 ) ,

21.segment: Significant decrease was found in C-reactive protein on day +7 ( p = 0.02 ) and in lymphocytes counts on day +3 and +7 ( p = 0.02 ) .

22.segment: The median number of days in hospital after RT was 11 ( range 4-78 ) .

23.segment: With a median follow-up of 60 days after LD-RT ,

25.segment: 11 ( 27 % ) died because of COVID respiratory failure and 4 ( 10 % ) died of other causes .

26.segment: CONCLUSIONS : LD-RT is a feasible and well-tolerated treatment that could lead to rapid clinical improvement .

27.segment: Large randomized trials would be required to establish the efficacy of LD-RT to treat COVID-19 pneumonia .
